scaledic 0.1.6

    Introduction to scaledic

    scaledic.rmd

    Note

    This is a short description on how to use the scaledic package. The following code examples in this package make use of the pipe operator %>% (see the magrittr package).
    Once you are used to the pipe operator, it makes code easier to read. Basically, it is just a shortcut. The pipe operator takes the return of the previous function and sets it as the first argument of the following function. An example:

    newdat <- select(dat, "iq", "age")
newdat <- describe(newdat)
newdat <- round(newdat, 2)
kable(newdat)

    or even worth

    kable(round(describe(select(dat, "iq", "age")), 2))

    becomes:

    dat %>%
  select("iq", "age") %>%
  describe() %>%
  round(2) %>%
  kable()

    How to use scaledic

    You need two things:

    1. a dataset,
    2. a dictionary file.

    A dictionary file

    A dictionary file is a table with a row for each variable and a column for each parameter of those variables. Most conviniently, you prepare a dictionary file in a spreadsheet program for later use with datasets.

    The following table shows the parameters and the naming of the columns of a dictionary file:

    Columns of a dictionary file
    Parameter Meaning Example
    label A short item label itrf_1
    scale Abreviation of the scale the item belongs to irtf
    sub_scale Abrevation of the sub scale int
    sub_scale_2 Abrevation of the second order sub scale shy
    scale_label Name of the scale Integrated Teacher Report Form
    sub_scale_label Name of the sub scale internalizing problems
    scale_2_label Name of the second order sub scale shyness
    item Full text of the item Vermeidet die Teilnahme an Diskussionen im Unterricht
    index An index number 1
    values Valid response values in an R manner 1:5 (for integers 1 to 5) 1,2,3 (for integers 1, 2, 3)
    value_labels Labels for each response value 0 = nicht; 1 = leicht; 2 = mäßig; 3 = stark
    missing Missing values -888, -999
    type Data type (factor, integer, float, real) integer
    weight Reversion of item and its weight 1 (positive), -1 (reverse), 1.5 (positive, weights 1.5 times)
    source Reference Casale et al. (2017)
    note Further notes Item has low descrimination

    Here is extract of a dic file from the included example:

    dic_ITRF %>% slice(1:3)  %>% kable()
    label index scale sub_scale SUB_SCALE_2 scale_label sub_scale_label sub_scale_2_label item weight values value_labels missing type source note
    itrf_I_1 1 ITRF Int SW Integrated teacher report form Internalizing Socially Withdrawn Verbringt zu viel Zeit alleine 1 0:3 0 = not problematic; 1 = slightly problematic; 2 = problematic; 3 = strongly problematic -99 integer Volpe et al. et al. (unpublished) NA
    itrf_I_2 2 ITRF Int AD Integrated teacher report form Internalizing Anxious/Depressed Beschwert sich über Krankheit oder Schmerzen 1 0:3 0 = not problematic; 1 = slightly problematic; 2 = problematic; 3 = strongly problematic -99 integer Volpe et al. et al. (unpublished) NA
    itrf_I_4 4 ITRF Int SW Integrated teacher report form Internalizing Socially Withdrawn Vermeidet soziale Interaktionen 1 0:3 0 = not problematic; 1 = slightly problematic; 2 = problematic; 3 = strongly problematic -99 integer Volpe et al. et al. (unpublished) NA

    Apply a dictionary file

    When you combine a dataset with a dictionary file, each variable in the dataset which corresponds to a variable described in the dictionary will be complemented with the given dictionary information.
    The resulting dataset now is ready to be used with all further scaledic functions.

    The apply_dic function takes the name of the dataset and the dictionary file and combines them. Thereby replacing missing values with NAs:

    # Here we use the example dataset "ITRF" and the example dic file "dic_ITRF"
dat <- apply_dic(ITRF, dic_ITRF)
#> Replaced missging values.

    Let us get an overview of all scales in the dataset:

    list_scales(dat, labels = TRUE, n_items = TRUE) %>%
  kable()
    Scale Subscale Subscale_2 Label scale Label subscale Label subscale 2 n Scale n Subscale n Subscale 2
    ITRF Ext APD Integrated teacher report form Externalizing Academic Productivity/Disorganization 36 17 8
    ITRF Ext OPP Integrated teacher report form Externalizing Oppositional/Disruptive 36 17 9
    ITRF Int AD Integrated teacher report form Internalizing Anxious/Depressed 36 19 11
    ITRF Int SW Integrated teacher report form Internalizing Socially Withdrawn 36 19 8

    Clean raw data

    Firstly, we check for invalid values in the dataset (e.g., typos) and replace these with NA:

    dat <- check_values(dat, replace = NA)

    Now we impute missing values:

    # Imputation for items of the subscale ITRF_Ext
dat <- impute_missing(dat, subscale = "Ext")
#> -- Imputation 1 --
#> 
#>   1  2  3

# Imputation for items of the subscale ITRF_Int
dat <- impute_missing(dat, subscale = "Int")
#> Warning: There are observations in the data that are completely missing. 
#>          These observations will remain unimputed in the final datasets. 
#> -- Imputation 1 --
#> 
#>   1  2  3

    Select scales for analyszing

    Let us see descriptive statistics for the Internalizing sub scale:

    dat %>% 
  select_scale(subscale = "Int") %>%
  psych::describe(fast = TRUE) %>%
  kable(digits = 1)
    vars n mean sd min max range se

    See items instead of labels

    And further we analyse the factor structure

  sjPlot::sjt.fa(nmbr.fctr = 4, wrap.labels = 70, show.comm = TRUE)

    Build scale scores

    Now we build scores for internalizing and externalizing scales

    dat$itrf_ext <- score_scale(dat, subscale = "Ext")
dat$itrf_int <- score_scale(dat, subscale = "Int")

    and get descriptives for these scores

    dat %>%
  select_scores() %>%
  psych::describe(fast = TRUE) %>%
  kable(digits = 1)
    vars n mean sd min max range se
    itrf_ext 1 4776 10.1 10.2 0 51 51 0.1
    itrf_int 2 4772 6.6 8.1 0 50 50 0.1
